sections.title: INTRO
sections.content:
## NO WORDS LEFT UNSAID… THIS WILL BE THE ONLY

## GUIDE YOU EVER NEED ON THE LEGS!

[CLICK HERE FOR   Discord Access (Direct Message me ON DISCORD AFTER you accept the invite to gain FULL ACCESS)](https://discord.gg/38qHCZ8wa8)

HAVE YOU EVER SEEN SOMEONE WITH A GREAT PHYSIQUE WHO HAS TOOTHPICK LEGS?

If you happen to fall into this category you will understand this deep to your core.

Unproportional, awkward, & injury prone.

And you will be reminded by your boys about your twig legs.

Any chance they get they will take that shot.

Training purely upper body is a one-dimensional way of physical training.

And I know this from experience considering I skipped leg day for the majority of my lifting career.

You are operating at 50-60% capacity and you know this deep down.

As a result of your process, you are consistently leaving your gains & capability on the table.

And it's never a good thing to leave Gains on the table.

LEGS ARE THE THOSE THINGS WE WALK ON EVERYDAY. BUILD THEM & YOU BUILD REAL POWER. FROM LIFTING HEAVY TO MOVING FAST. WHEN YOU TRAIN LEGS CORRECT, YOU UNLOCK EXPLOSIVE POTENTIAL & SET THE FOUNDATION FOR REAL GROWTH, WHICH INCLUDES UPPER BODY. DOMINANT FROM HEAD TO TOE.

If you truly have a STRONG set of legs…you will perform VASTLY better than the majority of people and that includes the aesthetics of your upper body going to a different level.

You release more testosterone from Leg training than ANY OTHER BODY PART.

That is how you are leaving a TON of Upper body gains on the table.

And coming from someone who skipped legs for the first half of his lifting journey…when I introduced legs into the mix my upper body gains went to another level, with denser looking muscle & detailing that really made a world of a difference.

Keep in mind these “new gains” were AFTER a HALF DECADE of pure upper body training.

It’s one of the places on your body where you get the most bang for your buck.

This is what this guide & my personal training philosophy is about .

The game is squeezing as much juice out the lemons you are provided with.

If you do that you win.

HAVE YOU SEEN SOMEONE WITH TERRIBLE POSTURE AND WALKING AROUND WITH A HUNCH?

People with POOR posture not only have awful physical stature but taking it a step further are extremely injury prone.

And it’s because your body is out of sorts…and posture is more than just your aura and physical stature…it’s the measure of health in a man.

Your posture plays a HUGE part in how your body looks, feels, and operates.

People overlook this crucial component & wonder why they look, feel, and operate much worse than they’d like to.

Even the guys who “think” they have it on lock…don’t .

A lot of this can be solved with direct posture training but it ALL STEMS from your   Legs  & your  Feet .

When your Leg Training is DIALED IN…this makes this part of the equation EFFORTLESS in fixing posture.



Just these few examples show you how imperative it is to your physique, raw physical power, and mobility.

But after this guide, you will now understand HOW to have your Leg Training on LOCK will give you more return on your time in the gym than any other muscle group on the body.

What's unbelievable and a harsh truth of physical training is that you can do minimal upper body work but if you execute on proper leg training.   You will look better than 99% of guys in the gym who have crazy arms and a big barrel chest.

This is one of the places on your body where you get more bang for your buck, which is an integral part of my training strategy as a whole.

Aesthetics, power, mobility, and complete control over your body with little to no chance of acquiring injuries.

That doesn’t mean just working your legs will take care of your upper body… but it domino effects.

And the first domino comes from those things you walk on.

THERE ARE FEW REASONS WHY PEOPLE WON’T EVER GET TO THIS POINT:

You are scared of hurting your Legs 1.

Struggle getting past the feeling of Leg Day Pain 2.

Not a clue which exercises will actually be EFFECTIVE 3.

No clue of proper technique in Leg Training 4.

Not executing your lifts properly 5.

And EVEN IF you know what exercises are most effective and you are executing your lifts properly, you don’t place them in the correct order to maximize results for your time & effort inside the gym

6.

But when you figure this out (which I will layout in this guide clearly) you will finally gain the momentum you’ve been looking for all these years.

It is a fact that your Leg Training is an IMPERATIVE thing to have on lock.

If your Legs aren’t up to speed with the rest of your body… you will suffer the consequences.

Those consequences aren’t just physical but rather mental.

Left frustrated, deflated, and unmotivated to continue on.

That stops today.

sections.title: MINDSET
sections.content:
## MINDSET

Legs are a polarizing muscle group with some very strong opinions.

Leg Day Supremacists who workout legs solely because “it's all that matters.”

Leg Day Disrespectors who stay skipping leg days for YEARS (me).

The “once a month” Leg Day Crew.

The gym rats who train them twice a week and separate posterior (Glutes & Hamstrings) and anterior (Quads).

I get why a lot of people skip leg day…

It’s Tortuous  1.

Requires Coordination & Conscious Action  2.

Doesn't give you the pump you are looking for  3.

A gnarly chest pump is cooler than a sick hamstring pump.

This is math & human nature.

For that reason… I myself didn’t lift legs for the first half of my training career.

Why?

Because “my legs are already big enough bro.”

“I walk on my legs all day…i don’t need to train legs.”

Quite Idiotic.

Little did I know the mental and physical agony I’d suffer from as a result.

But we will get to that...

And don’t get me starting on squatting... What a cluster fuck

“How am I supposed to squat?”

“Where should my feet be?”

Are my toes supposed to poke outward?”

“Should I narrow my stance or do I need to go wider?”

But it’s like anything else…when you first learned how to bench.

“Where do I touch the bar?”

“How do I situate my feet?”

It is all learned through  TIME & REPETITIONS .

You will find your groove and once you do…I promise you.

You’ll look back pissed at yourself for not hitting legs sooner.

But a lot of these answers DEPEND on on your goals.

If you are a “powerlifter looking to crush the world record” -I am not your guy.

If you are into Yoga and Meditation “woosa woosa” Breath Work Squatting- I am also not your guy.

But if you are somewhere in between where you want to be athletic, aesthetic, explosive, mobile, strong   VIA ALL NATURAL.

Creating a body that is HEAVILY resilient to injury- then I AM your guy.

My goal with this guide is to give you what you are looking for when it comes to effective leg training.

It’ll provide you exactly what you are looking for.

But before we get into that… I am going to share a quick story of what got me into Leg Training.

It wasn’t a strike of motivation or insight…it was because I had no other choice.

I got started lifting in high school but nothing serious.

Just picking up some weights and putting them down.

Pretty much exclusively training arms and chest (like a real gym bro).

Then when I got to college I started making it a staple of my life because it was the only thing I’d ever done for myself & it put me into a relentless mind frame.

I still had no idea what I was doing, so I did what everyone else was doing.

I started training harder, restricting my diet, and pouring more time & more energy into it.

I got some results, but they were massively underwhelming.

But after YEARS of effort, I wasn’t even close to looking how I wanted.

You know that physique where your arms fill out a medium-sized shirt but with no real definition…like chunky big body type (basically the average gym bro lifter body.)

The kinda physique where you’re a bit uncomfortable taking your shirt off at the beach because “you are the workout guy” with pudge.

That’s what I had.

No one is going to ask you “What’s your workout regiment bro?”

And the more effort I put into it, the more it felt like I was spinning my wheels- I was beginning to break.

Then one day a friend of mine asked me to play a quick game of pick-up basketball after my lift.

I told him no but he wouldn’t stop talking and I decided fuck it we can run a quick game.

Very beginning of the game, I went up for a rebound with no one in sight, came down and COMPLETELY blew out my knee.

Torn Meniscus, Torn ACL, Torn LCL, Torn MCL, & Partially Torn PCL. My knee was TORCHED. Forced to get reconstructive surgery.

I was super angered because I’d given everything to achieve the milk-toast physique I had and was fighting hard to keep it.

At the time it felt like it was over for me.  Turned out it was the best thing that could’ve possibly happened to me.

Because I finally realized why I do what I do.

See, when you’re in the habit of doing something you start taking it for granted & lose the genuine energy towards that thing because “it's just a part of my routine.”

But this injury ignited a relentless force within me. One that had always been there, but had been stuffed down & extinguished.

It was also the first time I realized that I reap what I sow in this life & that if I want to become undeniable, the details matter.

Again, I never trained my legs before that moment… EVER.

I got injured because I hadn’t trained my lower body to do shit besides walk from machine to machine.

I’d been pulling the wool over my own eyes.

Ignoring a critical aspect of my training because I didn’t want to do it.

I was soft physically & mentally.

Sitting in the hospital bed incapacitated, it became clear that achieving the vision in my head was going to require a more methodical and surgical approach.

That was when I really started to dive into the details that I was ignoring due to wanting to be “jacked and aesthetic bro.”

And there is more to this story but that started my leg day journey and led to me to the best shape of my life.

UNDERSTAND: Genetically I was never “meant” to look like this

But what I didn’t realize prior to years of trial and error is that it requires a lot more knowledge of the details than I gave credit for.

I didn’t realize how important some of the muscles in the lower body are when it comes to building injury resilience.

But all I found on the internet was Squatting and leg extensions…ridiculous.

Finding those answers was not easy

However, one of my greatest strengths is my ability to come up with creative solutions.

Meaning finding a different way to do things for superior results, and making my time as effective as possible.

After learning about how the body is meant to move biomechanically (how muscles are meant to move.)

I learned the direction of our muscle fibers and once I nailed this down…

It was free rein for me to come up with new effective exercises that you don’t see around.

Testing exercises that I thought would be genuinely effective.

Now were they all hits?

No but through that process… I have landed on quite the library of Leg Exercises that actually provide you the results you are after.

I am writing to document this for my old self.

Everything I wish I would have known when I got started.

I AM GIVING YOU THE SHORTCUT…CUT THROUGH ALL THE WEEDS AND LAND ON THE REAL STUFF.

Is it easy? No

Does it require actual work? Yes

Will it accelerate my progress? Absolutely

IF YOU ARE HERE, YOU DON’T HAVE A WORK ETHIC PROBLEM…YOU HAVE A KNOWLEDGE PROBLEM.

You simply do not know how these factors work together.

That's what I will write out in the rest of this guide.

Because I want to provide you with the  answers that matter.

So I am going to organize this guide into different sections.

You can choose to go to the section that you are struggling with most.

But I HIGHLY RECOMMEND going through this guide in FULL.

You can click on ANY section below to jump straight to the content that speaks to you. No endless scrolling required.

SECTIONS OF THE GUIDE:

The Undeniable Standard: Becoming a Natural Crusader

Anatomy

Strength

Muscle Growth

Mobility

Building Injury Resilience

The SNIPER’S Leg Day (The Leg Day Formula)

## THE UNDENIABLE STANDARD:  BECOMING A NATURAL CRUSADER

What does it mean to be Undeniable?

To be  undeniable  is to be unshakable; unforgettable. The type of presence that doesn’t merely exist but demands attention, even when silent.

An undeniable man doesn’t chase validation.

He commands it, simply by  being .

He isn’t swayed by fleeting trends or superficial praise or pursuits.

He is grounded, immovable, and magnetic.

Every man has to make this choice: to be undeniable or to be invisible.

This is the path of the Natural Crusader

This path isn’t for the faint of heart… it’s for the man who knows that  true power  comes from within, who’s ready to claim his place in the world.

As a Natural Crusader, you commit to living by an unbreakable code, a set of rules that turn effort into  impact , muscle into  presence , and discipline into absolute mastery.

These rules aren’t just words…they’re the steps to becoming the one who stands out, the one who leaves a mark so strong it’s unmistakable.  These rules are  the undeniable standard .

## RULES OF THE NATURAL CRUSADER:

RULES OF THE NATURAL CRUSADERS:

Lead with Heart, Die on Your Sword 1.

Empty the Energy Clip Every Day 2.

Never Go to Bed Hungry 3.

Make Every Decision from Strength 4.

Food is Fuel, Not Entertainment 5.

Burn the Past 6.

No Counting, Just Consuming 7.

Master Desire (Dangle the Donut) 8.

Walk Into the Storm 9.

Ignore Your Own Hype 10.

Live By Your Standard 11.

Reject All Shortcuts 12.

Wear Your Scars Proudly 13.

Face Fear as a Challenge 14.

If I had learned these 14 rules sooner, my life would be unrecognizable today. Click the video below to see each one explained and why they could be the turning point for you too.

These rules define what it means to be  undeniable.

They aren’t just principles, they’re a new way of being.

These rules are how you become unforgettable, how you become the man others want to follow, emulate, and respect.

This isn’t a phase…it’s a movement.

It’s a commitment to something greater than self.

A legacy that speaks without words.

If you’re ready, there’s no going back.

The choice is yours:   either take the hard road to becoming unforgettable or fade into the crowd.

This is about leaving a legacy so strong, so undeniable, that the world will never forget you.

Welcome to the standard of the Natural Crusader.

sections.title: ANATOMY
sections.content:
## ANATOMY

In order for us to build the base of our body correct…we must have an understanding of the anatomy.

“Am I really getting a science lesson from Uncle Rommy?”

Yes you are…

But unlike your former professors and teachers I am going to give you information that’ll SPEED up your strength, muscle growth & mobility.

Once you understand the anatomy of the Legs it's going to be 100x easier to:

Target the areas that will actually build your Legs 1.

Build your Legs PROPER STRONG through a Longer Range of Motion 2.

How to access those Longer Ranges of Motion 3.

ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THIS “BORING” INFORMATION IS EVERYTHING YOU’VE WANTED THE ANSWERS TO…

I will make it clear how to be as effective as possible with your time.

There are a TON of muscles in your Legs & versus throwing them all at you at once thinking you would even care to read through it.

I am going to start with basic and get more detailed as we move through (that way it's real EASY to follow.)

The best way to start is with a basic overview:

Anterior Chain (front of your legs) Posterior Chain (back of your legs)

People typically know about the both Anterior Chain & Posterior Chain.

But where people miss is they shift their focus onto the Anterior Chain and neglect the Posterior Chain which is where your POWER and ATHLETIC PROWESS come from.

So as a result, we are going to start with the muscles in the Posterior Chain Leg Muscles:

Erector Spinae Glutes Hamstrings  Calves

sections.title: Glutes
sections.content:
But within each of the 4 muscles listed above (glutes, hamstrings, calves, spinal erectors.) It goes layers deeper. Which is why we will start broad and get more specific.

Let’s start with the Glutes:

The glutes are the powerhouses in your butt, driving you to stand tall, push your legs back, and rotate your hips.  Allowing you to run faster, jump higher, and unleash more power. “Dude, I don't want to train my glutes. Is there really any downside to not having strong glutes?”

Well…absolutely because it sets off a chain reaction of problems:

When your Glutes are WEAK…the lower back is FORCED to overcompensate for movements that your glutes are SUPPOSED to handle…as a direct result of that a LARGE portion of the population have chronic lower back pain that worsens as they get older

1.

Weak glutes make it difficult to stabilize the pelvis…yeah that “anterior pelvic tilt” you complain about? Is BECAUSE you refuse to train glutes..this throws off your body’s PROPER alignment & creates further stress on the spine which creates “poor posture”

2.

The chain continues down to the joints in your knees and hips because they are taking on more load which increases risk of injury & worsens pain in those areas.

3.

Lastly…you are weaker as a result of your lifts and in your sport. Strong glutes play the role of generating power and when they are weak you limit your ability to generate more power

4.

For both gym-goers or even everyday folks who enjoy leisure activities  Focusing your efforts on the glutes isn’t just about aesthetics—it keeps the body stable, aligned, and resilient against pain and injuries. Having strong glutes and teaching your body how to unlock its power is where your performance gains are at.

Needless to say…if your glutes are weak, you’re leaving a TON of performance gains on the table.

Now the glutes are made up of 3 muscles:

Gluteus Maximus 1.

Gluteus Medius 2.

Gluteus Minimus 3.

Gluteus Maximus: The largest of the three gluteal muscles. And as you probably guessed… It powers most movements like sprinting, jumping, squatting, and contributes to overall athleticism.  It is a crucial component for building strength and explosive power through your hips and legs.

[Example Exercise for Gluteus Maximus: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/d0wZXa55gIc?feature=share)

[Barbell Hip Thrusts](https://youtube.com/shorts/d0wZXa55gIc?feature=share)

Gluteus Medius : This muscle helps with side-to-side movements & helps stabilize our hips. This is significant for both balance and building injury resilience, especially within your knees and lower back.  A sneaky muscle that unlocks a TON of BOTH athleticism and mobility

[Example Exercise for Gluteus Medius: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/9L__IsQ0HD0?si=Y3_9istOESLf6cu6)

[Sumo Deadlift](https://youtube.com/shorts/9L__IsQ0HD0?si=Y3_9istOESLf6cu6)

Gluteus Minimus : You could have guessed from the name alone…this area of glutes is the smallest of the three. This muscle however helps the gluteus medius stabilize your hips. Allowing our body to remain aligned. And is imperative for smooth movement. As a result it will help reduce BOTH Hip and Lower Back pain.

[Example Exercise for Gluteus Minimus: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/pKn8ST8oudM?si=7RhEZkTnwPZGoXcg)

[Side-Lying Leg Lift](https://youtube.com/shorts/pKn8ST8oudM?si=7RhEZkTnwPZGoXcg)

All three muscles in the Glute work together in sync.

Aside from the glutes being CRUCIAL for strength & explosiveness in any physical activity.

They INSTANTLY alleviate knee & lower back pain.

When it comes to building injury resilience…this muscle does A LOT of the heavy lifting.

Then you have BOTH your  Adductors & Abductors  which I know I didn’t mention earlier but it’s because it is a “Cousin” to the glutes:

The adductor muscles pull the legs toward the center of your body, like when you bring your legs together.

Strong adductors make even the simplest of movements like walking or running a smoother process.

They support both your Hips & Knees so they stay aligned correctly.

There are multiple muscles that make up the adductors:

Adductor Magnus:  The largest adductor muscle… it brings the thigh inward and stabilizes your hips during movements. Adductor Longus:  This pulls the legs together & supports balance during activities like lunges or even running Adductor Brevis:  This muscle provides support during side-to-side motions. Pectineus:  Facilitates Hip flexion and adduction Gracilis:  The most superficial adductor that stabilizes the legs & assists with inner thigh movements. Adductor Minimus:  A small muscle above the adductor magnus that helps with hip stability.

[Example Exercise for Adductors: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/JMD4sZEBePk?si=QPDAWJ6IkjkTN7tf)

[Copanhagens](https://youtube.com/shorts/JMD4sZEBePk?si=QPDAWJ6IkjkTN7tf)

Now let’s talk about the opposite part of this equation.

Abductor Muscles 3 of the 4 muscles in the abductors are the glute muscles we went over previously.

Abductor muscles  move your legs away from the center of your body, like when you step sideways or spread your legs apart.

These muscles, found on the outside part of your hips and thighs.

Strong abductors allow your hips to feel strong and offer more support to your back alleviating a ton of pains associated.

All 3 muscles of the Glute are involved in abduction (mentioned above.)

But there is one other muscle involved and that is not a part of the glute.

Tensor Fasciae Latae (TFL) The TFL helps you kick your leg out to the side while keeping your hips locked in when you're moving your body.

Allows the knee to stay stable and in place during lifts with the help of the iliotibial band (band of tissue that runs outside of the thigh).

With a strong TFL you have better balance & smoother reps while building resilience against injury.

I can not state this enough…if you are an athlete or someone who cares to be athletic & powerful...your hips are CRUCIAL & now you know why.

It's the centerpiece of your athleticism.

With strong & mobile hips…we can unlock a different level of power and explosiveness.

Allowing your physical performance to  SKYROCKET

[Example Exercise for the TFL: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/pKn8ST8oudM?si=7RhEZkTnwPZGoXcg)

[Side-Lying Leg Raises](https://youtube.com/shorts/pKn8ST8oudM?si=7RhEZkTnwPZGoXcg)

That wraps up the anatomy lesson on the glutes & hip

sections.title: Hamstrings
sections.content:
Next up is the one that athletes struggle with injury wise…and no it’s not the knee.

But the repeated story of the “hamstring strain” or “hamstring pull.”

The Hamstrings have 3 Muscles:

Biceps Femoris Semitendinosus Semimembranosus

Biceps Femoris : This muscle has two parts…the long head and short head on the outer portion of the leg.

Allowing us to bend the knee and extend our hip.

A strong biceps femoris improves speed & power while also helping to stabilize the knee joint.

[Example Exercise for Biceps Femoris: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/_VCcyoM5x0M?feature=share)

[Nordic Curls](https://youtube.com/shorts/_VCcyoM5x0M?feature=share)

Semitendinosus : This muscle is located smack dab in the middle of the back hamstring Which also bends your knee and extends your hip, much like the biceps femoris.

But the significance of having a strong semitendinosus is balance and full control of our body while building resilience against injury, especially with your knees & lower back.

[Example Exercise for Semitendinosus: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/pZ4Cf3mZT80?si=Hex5SJIKIqNPM2-7)

[Seated Barbell Good Mornings](https://youtube.com/shorts/pZ4Cf3mZT80?si=Hex5SJIKIqNPM2-7)

Semimembranosus : Now this muscle is found on the inner side of the

hamstring & underneath the semitendinosus.

Again it helps bend your knee, extend your hip,

but also allows us to rotate your leg inward. Building Leg Strength in a way that furthers stability, which makes it critical for powerful

movements & injury resilience.

[Example Exercise for Semimembranosus (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/90WIwJDkKb8?si=yVwYGoWEFJ_9LLyd)

[Glute Bridge (with feet elevated)](https://youtube.com/shorts/90WIwJDkKb8?si=yVwYGoWEFJ_9LLyd)

Let’s go a bit deeper with the Biceps Femoris :

As stated above…there are two parts (long head and short head) on the outer side of your thigh (as you can see from the photo.)

Biceps Femoris Long Head: The Long Head is the much larger portion of the Biceps Femoris This allows bending of the knee, extension of the hip, and helps us rotate the leg outward.

A pivotal muscle for powerful movements like sprinting & jumping.

Contributes a big portion to leg strength and is significant for anything that requires hip extension.

[Example Exercise for Biceps Femoris Long Head: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/HB9wcnBwrKs?si=VuEw23dvnYNSTT0T)

[Romanian Deadlift](https://youtube.com/shorts/HB9wcnBwrKs?si=VuEw23dvnYNSTT0T)

Biceps Femoris Short Head : The Short Head, although the smaller muscle in this equation, helps with knee bending.

However it does not assist in hip extension since it doesn’t cross the hip joint.

But the short head is more involved in stabilizing the knee  In terms of keeping our hamstrings healthy and injury resilient…this is the money maker.

Which is why it’s something to factor into our training because it keeps us fresh and training.

The Short Head of the body gives us a ton of extra juice in our training.

[Example Exercise for Biceps Femoris Short Head: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/vYtA61hKcMc)

[Leg Curls](https://youtube.com/shorts/vYtA61hKcMc)

sections.title: Erector Spinae
sections.content:
Let’s get into the next section of this anatomy lesson.

Although technically NOT a part of the “legs,” but this is a critical part of leg training & overall performance.

The Erector Spinae  Check out the diagrams below

As you can see the  Erector Spinae  are the muscles that run along your spine, from your lower ALL THE WAY to the back of your neck.  Here’s why they matter: You can imagine function wise they’d help you keep a straight back and lift your chest.

Obviously this muscle stabilizes the Spine  which allows the spine to stay steady when you move. It can bend & it can twist.

“But what are the actual benefits of it as it pertains to my goals?” BEAUTIFUL Posture

Because the erectors run all the way up to the back of the neck it DIRECTLY affects the posture of your body. Simply put…strong erectors translate to better posture, reducing that lingering back pain and limits the injuries that happen.

When   you are hitting squats, deadlifts, or any other leg movement inside the gym…the spinal erectors stabilize your back helping you lift in safer positions  Which allows for more effective execution.

And it is an athletic edge because of the ability to change direction with control.

The bottom line is that the erector spinae are key for a strong back, good posture, and crushing leg training.

Strengthening these muscles helps you move with better postural support on your lifts while improving your injury resilience.

[Example Exercise for Erector Spinae: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://www.youtube.com/shorts/AXbpcPCz_DE)

[Hyperextension Rows](https://www.youtube.com/shorts/AXbpcPCz_DE)

Now we have a common insecurity of most dudes inside the gym except for the genetically gifted.

You guessed it…Calves The Calf has 2 separate muscles:

Gastrocnemius  Soleus

Gastrocnemius: This is the muscle you have been trying to grow like there is no tomorrow  Forming the bulk of the calf.

It has two heads: The Medial Head- the one on the inside. The Lateral Head- the one on the outside. Responsible for plantar flexion & knee flexion.

“Uncle Rommy, what the hell does that mean?”

sections.title: Calves
sections.content:
Okay I wanted an excuse to flex my vocabulary…I got you.

Plantar flexion is your ability to point the toes.

Knee flexion is the ability to bend the knee when the foot is planted.

Now the significance of both working together is the increase in explosiveness.

This is why it's important for athletes looking to stabilize their bodies during dynamic movement or regular folk who are just standing for long periods of time.

But let’s go into the specific of the heads Lateral Head:

Located on the outer calf More involved in lateral stability and explosiveness Focus on training for athletic performance and explosiveness

EXERCISE OF CHOICE:

Growth: Single-Leg Calf Raises (On the Lateral Side) Athletic Performance: Box Jumps

Medial Head:

Located on the inner calf Assists in knee flexion and provides balance/stability Focus on training for stability and aesthetics

EXERCISE OF CHOICE:

Seated Calf Raises Standing Calf Raises (Toes In)

You can’t grow your calves because the “ACHILLES TENDON” takes over during the movement.

But there is a trick to get rid of this issue…

WHEN IT COMES TO THE EXERCISES TO GROW YOUR STUBBORN CALVES:

[This is the tempo you need to implement to see real gains for the first time in your life:  Click here](https://youtube.com/shorts/_gp4zLx00U8?feature=share)

We will get into the achilles tendon itself as we wrap this section up.

But first we need to get into the…

Soleus : This is located   underneath the gastrocnemius.

The soleus is pretty flat but a much broader muscle.

This muscle is why you can point your toes when your knee is bent. This is much more significant for endurance activities like walking or even standing for long periods of time.

But having a strong soleus will only help the stability & balance of the lower body during lower-intensity movements.

Now before we wrap up the posterior chain of the legs…

We have NOT a muscle…but rather a TENDON.

Not just any tendon but the STRONGEST tendon on the human body. Which is the achilles tendon.

Achilles Tendon: What is a tendon? A tendon is the connective tissue that attaches muscle to bone.

The Achilles Tendon connects the calf muscle & the heel bone.

The tendon itself helps you point your toes and push off the ground. This is why it is so essential for athletic and dynamic movement. As the strongest tendon on the human body it can handle RIDICULOUS force during explosive movement.

But despite its strength, it is prone to injuries which is why achilles tendons are an “out for the season” injury that leaves athletes a former shell of themselves.

The snap happens from sudden and overuse of explosive movement which why athletes need to be sure to have all of their muscles locked in.

This is why I have high attention to the details.

Now you understand why the posterior chain is so important for your power, athleticism, and mobility.

This is why I started with the posterior chain.

That concludes the posterior chain anatomy lesson.

But good news for you (and me) the next section will be a lot LESS dense!

sections.title: Quadriceps
sections.content:
With that said let’s go in the  Anterior Chain Leg Muscles :

Quadriceps  (Rectus Femoris, Vastus Lateralis, Vastus Medialis, Vastus Intermedius) Tibialis Anterior  (muscle that runs from the shin bone to the ankle)

Again within the quadriceps there are 4 separate muscles that make up the Quads:

Rectus Femoris Vastus Lateralis Vastus Medialis Vastus Intermedius

Rectus Femoris: This is the 2nd largest muscle in the Quad (despite most people thinking its the biggest.)

But it is the only muscle in the quad that crosses both into the Hip & Knee Joint.

Which makes it significant for both hip flexion (thigh towards the torso) and knee extension (straightening your knee).

Important for sprinting and jumping while supporting proper posture through stabilization of the pelvis floor during the movement itself.

[Example Exercise for Rectus Femoris: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/wbxSxWOn9Eg?si=JSO-9nNArsdhTqde)

[Reverse Nordics](https://youtube.com/shorts/wbxSxWOn9Eg?si=JSO-9nNArsdhTqde)

Vastus Lateralis: This is the LARGEST muscle in the Quadriceps which is located on the outside of the thigh and plays the role of stabilizing the knee.

The job of the vastus lateralis is BOTH knee extension & knee stability.

This allows us to further improved athletic performance while supporting the knee joint, which is why it allows us to build our injury resilience despite high-impact activities.

[Example Exercise for Vastus Lateralis: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/ZPRa8nvNNqo?si=dT-NRqdYa2wVO4FE)

[Cossack Dumbbell Squatt](https://youtube.com/shorts/ZPRa8nvNNqo?si=dT-NRqdYa2wVO4FE)

Vastus Medialis: Located on the inner portion of the thigh and is the teardrop on the quads you are after.

The VMO can be targeted directly through FULL RANGE OF MOTION lower body exercises.

It’s the muscle that helps keep the kneecap (patellar) in the right position which reduces chances of knee pain or injury.

It is absolutely significant for knee stability as a result and also assists the rectus femoris & vastus lateralis in knee extension.

This is the quadricep muscle that does the heavy lifting for resilience against knee injuries.

Absolving you of knee pains you may currently have.

This is huge for those of you with lingering knee pain and athletes in sports that require agility.

By strengthening the vastus medialis we maintain knee health with activities requiring quick changes in direction, like most sports.

[Example Exercise for VMO: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/_kr_7Ls-hxo?si=kWKP--2KHC8USX9c)

[Front Squats (FULL RANGE WITH A PAUSE AT THE BOTTOM)](https://youtube.com/shorts/_kr_7Ls-hxo?si=kWKP--2KHC8USX9c)

Vastus Intermedius: This muscle is underneath the rectus femoris which helps with overall strength of our quads.

It works with the other Quad muscles to straighten the leg for knee extension & offers overall support to the knee while we move.

Strengthening this muscle will help increase overall power of the quadriceps.

Improving strength directly enhances the stability of our knees.

[Example Exercise for Vastus Intermedius: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/vYtA61hKcMc?feature=share)

[Leg Extensions](https://youtube.com/shorts/vYtA61hKcMc?feature=share)

Overall:

Each Quadricep muscle is significant whether you are trying to improve strength, durability, or overall performance in any athletic activity. As a byproduct of nailing down movements that target these muscles, we increase our injury resilience.

Which brings us to the last subject of this anatomy lesson that felt like would never end. However this detailed information that you won’t see around is because the  DETAILS MATTER.  Understanding WHY we do what we do… only helps us gain clarity in getting the most bang for our buck.

Because you only have to learn this ONCE & it's yours forever and eventually becomes autopilot.

So, we spoke about the “Calf Muscle” earlier but that means we need dive into opposite side of this equation. That is the Tibialis Anterior

Tibialis Anterior: This is ONE muscle that runs from the shin bone to the ankle.

Plays a key role in dorsiflexion (lifting toes) & inversion (turning foot inward.)

Getting this muscle strong will help your walking pattern which is known as gait.

It increases ankle strength & positions the foot itself for more effective movement.

And perhaps the real reason to focus on strengthening them…it’ll support knee alignment which offers additional support to the knee.

So for those of you with knee problems this is a muscle to target in your routine.

By strengthening the tibialis anterior, you enhance your ankle stability while increasing injury resilience during high-impact activities. Proper foot positioning, balance, and knee alignment.

[Example Exercise for Tibialis Anterior: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/bgcBRv6fC64?si=-xrBaCPWwB1r7ZHS)

[Kettlebell Toe Raises](https://youtube.com/shorts/bgcBRv6fC64?si=-xrBaCPWwB1r7ZHS)

sections.title: Hip Flexors
sections.content:
Lastly we have a muscle that I didn’t mention earlier but I think is important to note.

Those things you complain about taking over during “Ab Training”.

But why are these important?

With strong hip flexors, you allow your body for LONGER Ranges of Motion along with better stability.

This will only drive more power & control during your leg training.

And if you are an athlete, you know the importance of hip flexor training.

DIRECTLY improves agility, speed, and control in all sports where fast & strong leg movement is required.

Let’s start with the PRIMARY hip flexor muscles:

Psoas (Minor & Major) Iliacus

Collectively these muscles are known as the iliopsoas group

But let’s breakdown both of these before we get into the meat & potatoes of this guide.

PSOAS: The Psoas Muscle has both a major and minor. But what’s crazy is that it’s normal for people to NOT have a psoas minor!

So let’s start with the one that everyone has:

Psoas Major: The major starts at the lower spine & connects to the thigh bone. This is the PRIMARY driver for lifting your knee up and forward

When it comes to explosive movements like sprinting or high jumps…this muscle is where a lot of your performance gains can be found.

Psoas Minor: The Psoas minor also begins at your spine but is a smaller muscle than the major (probably guessed that from the name).

This does help with flexion of the hip but not nearly as powerful as the major.

Essentially it just offers additional support in driving the knee higher and with stability of the core. This helps with both posture and overall balance

[Example Exercise of Psoas: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/HWu3LfM1zq8?feature=share)

[Reverse Squats](https://youtube.com/shorts/HWu3LfM1zq8?feature=share)

Iliacus This part of the hip flexor sits in your PELVIS and connects to the thigh and works in tandem with the psoas major.

This allows our hip joint to stabilize while allowing us to lift the thigh itself. Meaning it is responsible for keeping our hips both stable and supported.

Strengthening the iliacus directly allows our hips to stay PAINLESS. Keeps movements under smooth controlled movements whether we are lunging, squatting, or even when we throw a kick.

[Example Exercise for Iliacus: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/blQOb3eFwlo?si=zfeXWIdTHepXJ1Qg)

[Reverse Lunges](https://youtube.com/shorts/blQOb3eFwlo?si=zfeXWIdTHepXJ1Qg)

Well that wraps up our anatomy lesson and now let’s get into how we create a ridiculous set of legs.

sections.title: Biomechanics
sections.content:
Biomechanics: As you can see there are a ton of muscles within each muscle of the overview muscles of the legs. And all these muscles are important to have on point. And there is a ton of overlap to where we can do a lot at once. To where we can MAX OUT our effectiveness with a less time sacrificed.

And that is where the magic is.

But these muscles play a big part in your rotation…both external and internal.

“Why do I need to know this?”

Well I am about to give you the ONLY lesson in biomechanics you will ever need to know.

A lot of MOVEMENT is  ROTATION!

When you truly get a solid grasp on this basic lesson you will be able to execute each lift with pristine form leading to incredible muscle growth, strength gains, and avoiding injuries.

Let’s use a classic favorite exercise, the Barbell Back Squat.

With every lift there are two parts and both are equally as important as the other.

The  concentric/shortening/positive   portion of a rep (The Contraction).

During the process of completing a rep on a squat your muscles are internally rotating (internal rotation).

The  eccentric/lengthening/negative   portion  of a rep (The Stretch).

On the negative/eccentric portion of that rep your muscles are externally rotating (External Rotation).

This is why people have issues with their back and hips because they are so focused on the internal rotation portion of the rep and barely focus on the other half of the rep.

Improved range of motion through external rotation is so damn important.

And it does NOT need to be boring band work at your Physical Therapy appointment.

Whether you want strength, muscle growth, improved physical performance, or those striated legs you’ve been looking for.

This is going to get the job done without any boring old mobility work.

sections.title: STRENGTH
sections.content:
## STRENGTH

Building a strong set of Legs that can handle a TON of weight is mainly about proper exercise selection.

HOWEVER we must understand… As you get stronger the more things that can go wrong.

Just like a Supercar.

Let’s use a Mclaren as an example.

Mclaren’s are known to break down more often than the average car.

Why?

Because the output it is capable of is more than a Toyota Camry.

Meaning that there is more that can go wrong.

But good news for us is that we have FULL CONTROL over the tiny nuts and bolts involved in this entire system.

When you injure yourself, instead of thinking of it as a setback and that your life is over, think of it as your own body reporting back to you that there are things to fix.

I swear to you, every time I encountered an injury & fixed the problem (injury), both the amount of muscle & the strength  I developed BLEW past my previous markers.

It was like magic and when I realized the  significance of these “weird muscles”.

I began to look forward to exercising them.

Because it requires such little effort to get these muscles up to speed.

If you work to strengthen through LONGER RANGES OF MOTION… you effectively unlock real strength of those smaller muscles that can only be targeted through access to those longer ranges of motion.

And that is only going to help you get stronger in a way that translates to real life.

While unlocking real mobility and freedom of movement…you will see how strong you can actually get.

I will reiterate….the ability to build a strong set of legs is predicated on exercise selection, and we can use different set schemes to speed up this process versus constantly dealing with plateaus.

You should be hitting PR’s often and this will ensure you do so if you follow this exactly.

You are probably thinking of Squats.

“How complicated can squats be Uncle Rommy?”

THERE ARE 5 EXERCISES I USE TO MEASURE MY STRENGTH STANDARDS:

Front Squats Deficit Deadlifts Full ROM Back Squats (ROM=Range of Motion) Box Squats Wide Stance Zercher Squats

USE THESE 5 AT YOUR DISPOSAL AND CYCLE THEM WHEN YOU HIT PLATEAUS.

You will very quickly find the ROOT of where your issues are stemming from in your legs.

What I do for ALL STRENGTH WORK on LEGS is work up to a 3-4 Rep Max (setting a Personal Record).

Take a 3-4 minute break till you are recovered fully.

Then dropping the weight by 20% and get as many reps as humanly possible (setting a Rep Personal record at that 20% drop).

This is going to build your endurance to sustain heavy lifting.

You  should be doing one of these 5 movements listed as the VERY FIRST WORKING SETS INSIDE THE GYM.

And working up to that 3-4 Rep Max as quickly as possible.

And lifting for pure strength, of course we must have our form dialed in but none of that “slow all the way through” bologna.

Dial in on your form for the negative/eccentric portion of the rep and then explode on the rep/concentric portion of the lift.

“Focus on your form on the negative/eccentric portion of the rep” DOES NOT mean you need to go “turtle speed” , just dial in your form to where you are setting up for the press itself.

Now at this point we are now set up perfectly for the next phase of our lift.

This is where we move into growing the size of our Legs, turning them from a pathetic excuse of a Toothpicks to FINALLY growing the size of our Legs.

HOWEVER if you hit a   plateau  that you can’t break through…You want to take 1 of the 5 exercises I listed.

And do DYNAMIC EFFORT SETS-

“What is that & Why does this work?” Dynamic effort training focuses on lifting lighter weights as fast as you possibly can.

This method is designed to boost your  Rate of Force Development,  while max effort training builds your absolute strength, dynamic effort training is all about helping you generate a lot of force quickly.  This means better bar speed for lifters and improved performance in sports.

Because   Force= Mass X Acceleration Acceleration is a part of the force equation.

You want to go 50-70% of your 1 Rep Max and do 8 Sets of 3 Reps. Every Rep is meant to be as fast as humanly possible…WHILE maintaining pristine form. Give yourself 1-2 minutes to recover between sets.

But that is the only reason why you need to pull out that tool in that toolbox.

Or if you just want to change it up which is always a good thing in my book. Otherwise, you can do one of these 5 exercises listed as the VERY FIRST WORKING SETS INSIDE THE GYM.

That concludes the first portion of our lift which is HYPER FOCUSED on strength.

Now at this point we are set up perfectly for the next phase of our lift. This is where we move into growing the size of our Legs, turning them from a stick- figures to Running Back set of legs.

sections.title: MUSCLE GROWTH
sections.content:
## MUSCLE GROWTH

INTRODUCING THE LEG DAY FRAMEWORK: The legs respond to this thing known as “Muscle Stress”.

Basically the point in the set “when it really burns”.

DOUBLE DOWN!

Your Legs respond best to this type of intensity.

Intensity is your new best friend.

Your legs are stubborn to grow because you are scared of sitting in the uncomfortable and IF you implement with the right inputs & intensity, no matter how shit your leg genetics are…. they will grow, that's a promise.

The Legs are malleable like most other muscles.

Now most people think “well… I already hit my quads on squats, that's good enough,” I disagree.

You were training them for STRENGTH versus MUSCLE GROWTH.

Two entirely different ball games.

REMEMBER, we are snipers!   Precise, accurate, and nail the target between the eyes.

Unlike machine gun sprayers where they pull the trigger hoping to get lucky, this leaves you very LITTLE chance to fail.

But how do we implement it in a way that does just that?

SUPERSETS & Single Leg Biased Lifts:

Compound lift SUPERSET with an isolation exercise on the SAME MUSCLE Single Legged Lifts in different planes

EXAMPLE FOR SUPERSET ON QUADRICEPS:

Front Squat (Compound Lift) followed by Leg Extensions (isolation exercise)

EXAMPLE FOR SUPERSET ON HAMSTRINGS:

Dumbbell RDL’s (Compound Lift) followed by Leg Curl Machine (isolation exercise)

EXAMPLES FOR THE SINGLE LEG EXERCISE:

Cossack Squats DB Lunges (all different planes) Bulgarian Split Squats Etc.

2-3 sets on each all till failure!

The kicker is you want to be failing between  5-9 reps  on the  compound lift.

Then on the  Isolation  exercises, you want to be failing between  6-11 reps followed by  partials.

This is simply placing our exercises in a way that gives us as much sustained effective mechanical tension on the muscle for as long as humanly possible till our body gives.

For Single Legged movements you want to pick something that you can identify limitations in your legs.

This is why I love cossack squats.

Because Leg training is all about how to move heavier weights at LONGER RANGES OF MOTION. This will help your hips and back to feel 100x stronger but recruits more muscle fibers due to the access.

You see mobility and muscle are actually one of the same when you implement it in this way. It's where the bridge crosses over because in the process of working on mobility and furthering access to new ranges of motion…

The more muscle you put onto your legs, the more energy you burn, the more injury resilient you become, and the more your strength will translate to activities outside of the gym.

This is what people miss with Leg Training. It requires less time and somehow manages to give you better results than everyone.

UNDERSTAND THIS NEW WAY OF HITTING YOUR LEGS WILL LEAVE YOU GASSED, SWEATING PROFUSELY, ANGERED, AND EXHAUSTED, BUT YOUR LEGS WILL GROW!

You are overwhelming the muscle to a point it has legitimately no choice but to grow and get stronger.

And obviously you can plug and play different exercises as long as it generally fits the framework..just make sure your supersets are doubling up on the same muscle. And your single legged exercises are dialed in technique wise.

Working on accessing certain planes, finding sticking points in your mobility, where you lose balance, where you feel weak, etc.

sections.title: INJURY RESILIENCE & MOBILITY
sections.content:
## INJURIES & LACK OF MOBILITY

## (INJURY RESILIENCE):

I have many friends who have completely jacked up their knees, hips, and lower backs. Some from the army, from sports, or just weightlifting in the gym. And if you happen to know or be one of these guys, it completely tanks your way of life. Limited at every turn, have to be cautious all the time, and second guess every action.

WHEN LIFE IS LIVED LIKE THIS, YOU ARE ACTIVELY SUPPRESSING YOURSELF AND LIVING A LIFE IN HANDCUFFS.

And what's terrible there was not a damn thing you can do about it, until now. Think about what life was like before your fucked up knees, hip and lower back.

I want you to move with COMPLETE FREEDOM and with ZERO hesitation.

I want you to get back to that guy throwing caution to the wind with ZERO FEAR of what could go wrong.

You are playing life on your heels, you are playing life not to lose, you are playing defense.

No one likes to play life on the defense of what could go wrong, constantly factoring different possibilities of what could go bad.

What if you could completely trust yourself to do whatever it was your mind TRULY desired, having the conviction to know that no matter what I do I can not injure my body even if I tried with all my might and will to do so.

THAT’S WHO THIS SECTION IS FOR.

Having big strong tree trunks is more than just looking like an absolute unit (although very cool and has shit load of perks).

It’s about knowing that ½ of your body (being your lower body) is so dialed in with its training that no matter what… you are operating at your PEAK.

Imagine the energy tap that presents itself to you on the other end.

But what most fail to realize… The muscles you are neglecting or possibly don’t even know exist, act like an army. The more skilled soldiers you have on your team the better the results of the war become.

This guide will CHANGE the game for you.

Because there aren’t many people who have dove into the details the way I have. Suffering from injuries that led me into hospital beds is why I was forced to respect the details of the game.

Again when you suffer from an injury… your body is providing you feedback.

It is telling you that you have CHINKS and WEAKNESSES in your armor. It's your job to identify WHY it went wrong & then fix those issues.

But you don't have to do it alone anymore, because Uncle Rommy has your back.

Injury Resilience has very little to do with gimmicky mobility sequences and more so to do with picking exercises that help us better facilitate new ranges of motion…and getting stronger from those ranges.

If you could pause squat 315 lbs for reps for multiple sets…do you think you’d injure easily?

Of course not…because you have effectively loaded your body with several pounds on your traps in a “compromised” position. And THEN rep 315 lbs ferociously from that weighted stretch position.

I consider mobility weighted stretching with load and then executing lifts from those stretched positions with ferociousness.

Your lack of mobility, terrible posture, and low levels of strength on certain exercises is why you walk on eggshells or find yourself tweaking something every month.

Learning how to increase your Range of Motion on the leg exercises you are currently doing is going to move the needle for you more than any sequence.

Examples:

Squatting 1.

Progressing into Ass to Grass…hold it for 3 seconds at the bottom and then explode up Romanian Deadlifts 2.

Learn how to push your hips back and progress into lower and lower positions and explode into the rep Cossack Squats 3.

Learning how to rep side to side getting a bit deeper into each side of the lunge…IDENTIFYING the mobility difference between your left & right hip. The difference in your right and left ankle mobility & strength Nordic Curls: 4.

There have been several studies done with athletes who programmed these into their routine have shown Nordics help prevent hamstring injuries by SIGNIFICANT MARGIN…this is due to the eccentric muscle strength required to lower your body controlled There was also a study that went into the joint angles between Nordics and Sprinting..at peak hamstring activation during a nordic was very similar to the joint angles during sprints Reverse Nordics: 5.

According to Alonso-Fernandez et al. 2019…this study was based on 8 weeks of Reverse Nordics that led to an increase in muscle thickness, length, and cross-sectional area in the rectus femoris.  The movement itself targets primarily the rectus femoris AND the vastus medialis (that's the teardrop on the quads gym bros are after)...But this is the muscle to focus on for injury resilience making it an incredible rehab movement that also happens to put muscles onto our quads. This is what my training is all about…getting the best of all areas of training

Just these movements alone…  If you get these on lock you will build a body that is very difficult to break.

## EXTRA MOBILITY/INJURY RESILIENCE EXERCISES

Mobility is factored into our exercise selection. HOWEVER, If you want to take it up a level, this will require some extra time (minimal).

But if you are lifting the way you are supposed to this should not be an issue.

When you increase your range of motion on your exercises through improving mobility, you recruit more muscle fibers in the movement leading to greater muscle growth, and strength through a LONGER range of motion.

Its a no fucking brainer but if you want to take your mobility up a notch, these are exercises I would work on exactly what you do: (CLICK EACH EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)

[Weighted Plate Mobility Cossack Barbell Squats Cossack Dumbbell Squats Reverse Nordics Standing Good Mornings Full Body Mobility Movement  Nordic Curls](https://youtube.com/shorts/YF638a7sx5g?si=L2pbm61lgVEm2heJ)

Do these exercises and you will instantly feel relief!

It’s that type of pain where you have incredible relief afterwards.

But you are getting stronger through lengthened positions (fancy term for stretched positions)

HEALING PREVIOUS TEARS AND ELIMINATING PAIN

This is probably what some of you have been waiting for. How tf do I work around my jacked up knees? Understand before we get into this…my exercise selection are HEAVILY focused on rehab movements.

Because  REHAB=STRENGTHENING

But we also want to offer a way of progressing. Start with backwards walking on the treadmill & tibialis raises for your knees. Hip Adduction and Hip Abduction machine to get your hips nice and strong.

These are great entry level exercises to get your body started without it being so overwhelming on your body.

Think of it like soldiers in a war.

The more soldiers you have going into a war the better off you will be.

Problem is you have no defense system. Your defense system is the muscles surrounding your joints along with tendon strength.

That is why it is SO IMPORTANT to execute on FULL RANGE OF MOTION leg exercises because you are strengthening your tendons in the process of growing your muscles…if your muscles are stronger than your tendons that is where people get injuries.

If you don't have that in line, then the building will fall. This is why I am a mobility respecter.

Get stronger on these lifts, get your numbers up and take it to failure.

sections.title: THE SNIPER'S LEG DAY
sections.content:
## THE SNIPER’S LEG DAY (THE LEG DAY FORMULA)

There you have it, everything top to bottom. The gold mine is yours

“But how do we put it together Uncle Rommy?” Okay you win, I will do you this solid. (CLICK EACH EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)

[Front Squats Deficit Deadlifts Full ROM Back Squats (ROM=Range of Motion) Wide Stance Box Squats: Zercher Squats](https://youtube.com/shorts/zL8Zjx6jmt0?si=J27wiUlYWuUhgMvV)

Set 1: 3-4 Rep Max Set 2: Drop 20% & Set Rep PR

Explanation: Work up to a 3-4 Rep Max for 1 Set

Take a 3-4 Minute Break

Then drop the weight by 20% and set a REP PR

4.Single Legged Quad Exercise  (Pick 1):

5.Hamstring SUPERSET Exercise (2-3 Sets):

[1st Hamstring Movement Fail between 8-12 Reps (Pick 1):](https://youtube.com/shorts/vYtA61hKcMc)

[Leg Curls Deadlifts Zercher Deadlifts Zercher RDL’s Nordic Curls (as many reps as you can do) 2nd Hamstring Movement Complete Failure  (Pick 1):](https://youtube.com/shorts/ctgmcE6dFqY?si=B_GanDYlheWJR3Vv)

[DB RDL’s Barbell RDL’S Reverse Hyperextensions](https://youtube.com/shorts/HB9wcnBwrKs?si=VuEw23dvnYNSTT0T)

6.Quadriceps: 3 Sets  (Pick 1):

[Leg extensions (Fail between 7-11 Reps) SS with Sissy Squats (AMRAP till COMPLETE FAILURE)](https://www.youtube.com/shorts/vYtA61hKcMc)

[Leg Extension Video Sissy Squat Video Cossack Dumbbell Squats: (Fail between 8-10 Reps Each Side) Cossack Barbell Squats: (Fail between 8-10 Reps Each Side) Hindu Squats (Fail between 7-11 Reps) SS with Sissy Squats (AMRAP till COMPLETE FAILURE)](https://youtube.com/shorts/HysJpbWUviQ?feature=share)

[Hindu Squat Video Sissy Squat Video Reverse Nordics (as many reps as possible)](https://youtube.com/shorts/HysJpbWUviQ?feature=share)

[7.Injury Resilience  (Pick 1):](https://youtube.com/shorts/9cf-P4JVeU8?feature=share)

[Backward walking on the treadmill: 5-10 minutes Copenhagen’s: 2-3 Sets PER LEG (AMRAP...force the weaker leg to keep up) Pistol Squats: 2-3 Sets PER LEG (AMRAP...force the weaker leg to keep up) Reverse Hyperextensions: 3 Sets @ 10-15 Reps Side-Lying Leg Raises: 3 Sets @ 15-20 Reps each side](https://youtube.com/shorts/JMD4sZEBePk?si=QPDAWJ6IkjkTN7tf)

8.Calves SuperSet (3 Sets)
