sections.title: INTRO
sections.content:
## NO WORDS LEFT UNSAID…THIS WILL

## BE THE ONLY GUIDE YOU EVER NEED

## ON THE SHOULDERS!


Now before we get into the action information, it’s important to understand that there are 3 serious problems we’re aiming to fix here:

Small Shoulders Injured Shoulders Weak Shoulders

Maybe you suffer from just one…

Maybe you suffer from two…

Maybe you even suffer from all three…

Doesn’t matter, because they’re all as bad as each other.

HAVE YOU EVER SEEN SOMEONE WHO HAS INJURY RIDDEN SHOULDERS?

If you happen to fall into this category you will understand this deep to your core.

Limited, miserable, and suppressed. You are reduced to implementing self-limitations with how you lift. The physical activities you choose to partake in, and as a result consistently leaving a lot of capability on the table.

You are operating at 50-60% capacity and you know this deep down and it's FRUSTRATING!

## THIS AREA OF THE BODY

## IS AN ACTUAL CHEAT CODE AND IS THE KEY

## TO THE PHYSIQUE YOU’VE BEEN CHASING

HAVE YOU SEEN SOMEONE WITH A GREAT OVERALL PHYSIQUE AND LACK LUSTER SHOULDERS?

You will be looked at like you are in “alright shape”

Doesn’t matter how undeniable the rest of your physique is.

If you don't have solid shoulders and you will be looked at as nothing more than the average “weight lifter physique”.

Because if you truly have a strong set of shoulders…you will look better than the VAST majority of people who workout consistently inside the gym.

It’s one of the places on your body where you get the most bang for your buck.

This is what this document and my training philosophy is ALL ABOUT.

The game of life is simply squeezing as much juice out the lemons you are given.

HAVE YOU SEEN SOMEONE WITH TERRIBLE POSTURE AND WALKING AROUND WITH A HUNCH?

All these guys deal with pains and injuries doing the slightest of action.

Your shoulders have a HUGE part in how your body looks, feels, and operates.

It's the centerpiece that people overlook and wonder why they look, feel, and operate like everyone else inside the gym. Even the guys who “think” they have it on lock know they aren’t in any way, shape, or form impressive.

Just these few examples show you how imperative it is to your physique, raw physical ability, looseness, and mobility.

But on the flip side, this goes to show that having your shoulders on LOCK will give you so much return on your time in the gym.

You can have a lackluster physique but if you have strong and sculpted shoulders…

You will look better than 99% of people in the gym who have crazy arms and a big barrel chest.

This is one of the places on your body where you get more bang for your buck, which is an integral part of my training strategy as a whole.

Aesthetics, power, mobility, and complete control over your body while building injury resilience.

THERE ARE FEW REASONS WHY PEOPLE WON’T EVER GET TO THIS POINT :

You are scared of hurting your shoulders 1.

Don’t know what exercises hit specific parts of the shoulder 2.

Not a clue which exercises will actually move the needle for you 3.

And if you do know what exercises are most effective, you aren’t executing your lifts properly 4.

And EVEN IF you know what exercises are most effective and you are executing your lifts properly, you probably aren’t placing them in the correct order to give you the most results for your time and effort inside the gym

5.

But when you figure this out (which I will lay out in this guide clearly) you will finally gain the momentum you’ve been looking for all these years.

It is fact that the shoulders are an IMPERATIVE muscle group to have on lock.

If your shoulders aren’t up to speed with the rest of your body you will suffer the consequences that’ll leave you frustrated, deflated, and unmotivated to continue on.

But no more...

## MINDSET

My shoulders were proportionally small compared to my arms. Mediocre in strength, injured  CONSISTENTLY ,  and what's worse…  I was stiffer than a cardboard box. In an ongoing rough spot with my shoulders… genetically awful and I believed that was my fate.

Playing the “I am a victim of genetics” card did me ZERO FAVORs. It got me absolutely nowhere and I was wrong to do that. So…out of pure anger and self-disgust, I bulldozed my way to the answers.

And now years later I look like this. But what I didn’t realize prior to years of trial and error…

It required more knowledge of the details than I gave credit for. Not comprehending how SIGNIFICANT the muscles in your back are when it comes to shoulder and upper body health.

But all I found on the internet was shoulder presses and lateral raises… which is ridiculous.

Finding the answers was not easy to say the least.

However, one of my greatest strengths is my creativity, finding a different way to do things for better results, and maximizing my time.

A deep dive into the biomechanics of the body…how muscles are meant to move, the direction of our muscle fibers, etc.

And once I nailed this down… it was free rein for me to cook up new effective exercises that you don’t see anywhere else.

Constantly testing exercises that I thought could be effective.

Now were they all hits?

Absolutely not …  but through that process I landed myself a LIBRARY of shoulder exercises that provide the results we are after.

I am writing to document this for my old self.

Everything I wish I would have known when I got started.

I AM GIVING YOU THE SHORTCUT…CUT THROUGH ALL THE GARBAGE AND PROVIDE YOU WITH THE REAL STUFF.

Is it easy? No

Does it require actual work? Yes

But this WILL accelerate your progress QUICKLY.

YOU DON’T HAVE A WORK ETHIC PROBLEM… YOU HAVE A PROPER KNOWLEDGE PROBLEM.

You simply do not know how this shit works.

That's what I will write out in the rest of this guide.

Because I want this for you.

I am going to organize this guide into different sections so feel free to choose the section that you are struggling with most.

BUT I HIGHLY recommend going through the entire guide.

You can click on ANY section below to jump straight to the content that speaks to you. No endless scrolling required.

SECTIONS OF THE GUIDE:

- The Undeniable Standard: Becoming a Natural Crusader 
- Anatomy 
- Strength 
- Muscle Growth 
- Injury Resilience 
- Mobility 
- Healing previous tears and Eliminating Pain 
- The SNIPER’S Shoulder Day (The Shoulder Day Formula)

sections.title: ANATOMY
sections.content:
## ANATOMY

If we want to build the shoulder PROPERLY…we need to have an understanding of its anatomy.

“Uncle Rommy I am not here for a science lecture…I am here for capped out shoulders that garner me the attention I crave”.

Believe it or not, unlike your current or former teachers, I will provide you information that will only HELP better facilitate getting you a Greek Statue Esque Physique .

Once you understand the anatomy of the shoulder it makes it 100x easier to:

Get them obscenely strong 1.

Target specific portions of the shoulder (like a sniper) that will ACTUALLY build & sculpt out your shoulders

2.

Become Injury Resilient  3.

ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THIS “BORING” INFORMATION IS EVERYTHING YOU’VE WANTED THE ANSWERS TO…

I will make it clear how to be as effective as possible with your time.

There is a lot more to this than just the “shoulder itself” and when you look at the shoulder from the lens that I will share with you in this document..it’ll be crystal clear as to how many gains you were leaving on the table.

But for the sake of doing this correctly…the anatomy lesson we will start with the Deltoid (Shoulder).

Okay no more anatomy and you probably didn’t even go through the anatomy section (big mistake).

Anyways… you are here now and we can get into it now!

We start with the very first portion of your shoulder day lift because when we nail all this stuff above…

It sets us up to maximize our shoulder days!

From strength, muscle growth, to those striated capped out shoulders you’ve been looking for…

I promise this is going to do it for you.

sections.title: The Deltoids
sections.content:
The Deltoid (shoulder) has 3 separate heads:

@[Front Delts (Anterior Deltoid)](anatomy:front_delts) 
@[Side Delts (Lateral Deltoid)](anatomy:side_delts) 
@[Rear Delts (Posterior Deltoid)](anatomy:rear_delts) 

![](shoulders/page14_img1.jpeg)

Each of these muscles that make up the shoulder play a different role from the next.

Whether we are talking about movement, strength, and aesthetic Proper allocation of energy towards each these heads will not only build you some 3D Deltoids with beautiful size and shape  BUT will add strength while furthering the stability of the shoulder itself.

Obviously by NOT IGNORING any of the 3 heads we will greatly improve performance while building injury resilience And what better place to start this baby off with what I BELIEVE is the most IMPORTANT part of the shoulder.



Overview: Each deltoid head contributes to both our stability & control of weight which is only going to increase your strength numbers… regardless if you are executing a pressing or pulling movement.

And training all 3 heads will give you….

You guessed it **3D Shoulders**.

That Round, Complete Look allowing the aesthetics of your upper body to level up from your peers. You will look much more athletic & much more powerful.

That concludes our anatomy lesson on the Deltoid but like I said there is more to this than those 3 heads of the shoulder itself.

sections.title: Rear Delts
sections.content:
@[Posterior Deltoid (AKA the REAR DELTS](anatomy:rear_delts)): 

If you are familiar with my work you know that I am a REAR DELT SUPREMACIST.

And not just because it’s fun to say.

![](shoulders/page15_img1.jpeg)

People typically know about the front and side part of the shoulder but not very many people understand that there is the “back part of the shoulder” and even if you do know that…

You think it's an “afterthought”.

I’ve heard more people say than I can count “I'll throw it in at the end maybe or just put it on a back day”.

** You aren’t taking advantage of this SIGNIFICANT muscle properly.**


The rear deltoid moves your arm backward and helps with any and all pulling movements. Allowing our shoulder to stabilize during back-focused movements.

By building Rear Deltoid STRONG…your posture improves as a side effect, preventing your shoulders to round and as a direct result of that …we balance out the much more dominant head (front deltoid) to reduce our risk for shoulder injuries.

And as an added side bonus if you build these properly ... .your bench, shoulder press, and back lifts would BLOW TF UP!

And those round & capped out shoulders that you think are only reserved for steroid abusers?

Yeah you’d have those too without the risk of heart failure and an early grave.

This is why I am a Rear Delt Supremacist because there is a lot of gains you are leaving on the table by not prioritizing this head of the deltoid

## Exercise Examples for Rear Delts
!videos[hip_huggers, triple_rear_delt_delight, face_pulls_back]

sections.title: Side & Front Delts
sections.content:
Next comes the MOST AESTHETIC muscle head of the deltoid.

Lateral Deltoid (AKA Side Delts):

There is a reason why I call this muscle the MOST AESTHETIC of the 3. This is because it is responsible for developing PROPER WIDTH to your shoulders. With the added width to your shoulders this will ONLY help to enhance the V-Taper we all are after. Adding to the aesthetic of your upper body.

[EXERCISE EXAMPLE FOR THE SIDE DELTOID: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/cPt2OMDmwps?feature=share)

[Lateral Raises](https://youtube.com/shorts/cPt2OMDmwps?feature=share)

Next comes to the part of the shoulder that is the primary powerhouse.

Anterior Deltoids (AKA Front Delts): The front deltoids allow us to move our arms forward which is why it is the powerhouse of the shoulder. HEAVILY involved in all pressing movements whether we are talking overhead pressing for shoulders itself or even bench pressing for chest. The Front Deltoid is significant in developing REAL POWER. Taking it beyond performance… building our front delts will only enhance our upper chest appearance allowing our bodies to look more full while contributing to overall size and strength.

[EXERCISE EXAMPLE FOR THE FRONT DELTOID: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/H9il_PZegSE?feature=share)

[Standing Military Press](https://youtube.com/shorts/H9il_PZegSE?feature=share)

sections.title: The Rotator Cuff
sections.content:
The question we need to ask ourselves is… “But what supports the shoulder joint itself?” Great question!

The rotator cuff (I’m sure you’ve heard of this). You know that pain you get in your shoulder when you bench? Yeah that's because your rotator cuff muscles are weak because you neglect them.

“But what is the rotator cuff exactly?” The  rotator cuff  itself is your shoulder’s built-in support system that stabilizes the joint and allows it to move freely.  Regardless…whether we are talking about strength, aesthetics, or purely injury resilience…. it’s critical.

You’ve got 4 muscles that make  up the rotator cuff:

- @[Supraspinatus](anatomy:supraspinatus)  
- @[Infraspinatus](anatomy:infraspinatus) 
- @[Teres Minor](anatomy:teres_minor) 
- @[Subscapularis](anatomy:subscapularis) 

![](shoulders/page18_img1.jpeg)



Let’s get into EACH of the 4 muscles & their primary roles within the rotator cuff (I’ll make it quick)

### The Supraspinatus
This is how you are able to initiate lateral raises…this part of the rotator cuff allows you to lift your arm to the side


### The Infraspinatus 
This part of the rotator cuff helps you rotate your arms EXTERNALLY. This is important because most our posture and shoulder health issues stem from TOO MUCH INTERNAL ROTATION. Which makes it pivotal for posture & balancing out the internal rotators along with providing stability during pressing movements


### The Teres Minor
This part of the rotator cuff works WITH the infraspinatus for external rotation & stability of the shoulder itself. They coordinate together to keep our shoulders from rolling forward which better facilitates ….you guessed it. Posture & symmetry in your physique



### The Subscapularis
Now this part of the rotator cuff allows us to internally rotate the arm. This is in opposition to the infraspinatus & teres minor. The subscapularis provides balance with shoulder movements especially when we are pressing or hitting cable flyes.


# These muscles help build INJURY RESILIENCE.


![](shoulders/page19_img1.jpeg)

**Overview: The rotator cuff as a whole keeps your shoulder joint in place during heavier lifts…whether thats overhead pressing, lateral raises, chest fly variations, etc.**

And when we train these muscles properly…we prevent our shoulders from rolling forward which is not only going to improve your physical stature but your shoulder health.

Even aesthetically it prevents muscle imbalances between the front & back part of your shoulders which will only help you build muscle symmetrically.

And when our rotator cuff is WEAK…we improve our chances of impingements, tendonitis, and God forbid tears in your shoulders All typically sparked from some variation of pressing movements A strong rotator cuff will only allow you to build resilience against possible injuries.

**These muscles help build INJURY RESILIENCE.**

The rotator cuff muscles are the foundation for strong, healthy shoulders.

It’s only going to keep your posture in check, improve shoulder aesthetics, and help you avoid injuries.

# THE 3 EXERCISES FOR COMPLETE ROTATOR CUFF WORK:

@[Face Pulls](exercise:face_pulls) 
@[Dumbbell Shoulder External Rotations](exercise:dumbbell_shoulder_external_rotations) 
@[LU Raises](exercise:lu_raises) 




Obviously you can gather that these muscles play a big part in your rotation…both external and internal.

But it goes even a step further to hammer home the point because this lesson in biomechanics is truly a game changer for shoulder training.

When you truly get a solid grasp on this basic lesson you will be able to execute each lift with pristine form leading to incredible muscle growth, strength gains, and avoiding injuries.

Let’s use an exercise on the topic, the **Dumbbell Shoulder Press**.

With every lift there are two parts and both are equally as important as the other.

1.) The  **eccentric/lengthening/negative**  portion of a rep (The Stretch).

On this portion of the Press your muscles are externally rotating (External Rotation).


![](shoulders/page20_img1.jpeg)

2.) The  **concentric/shortening/positive**  portion of a rep (The Contraction).

During the process of completing the press your muscles are internally rotating (internal rotation).

![](shoulders/page21_img1.jpeg)

When you take this knowledge with you on your lifts and are MINDFUL of how your body is supposed to move.

Watch how your strength increases.


## I CALL THIS THE “THE IGNORED MUSCLE”, THE MUSCLE THAT GETS ABSOLUTELY NO TIME OF DAY.

Watch how you are able to lock into the muscle that much more focused. When you instinctively understand how the muscle is supposed to move.

You will be between the lines… people don’t grow because they don’t understand the details of the fundamentals.

Why and how am I supposed to lift this weight? You will feel all those smaller muscles aimed to help you become stronger.

People have issues with their rotator cuff because they are so focused on the internal rotation portion of the rep and barely focused on the other half of the rep.

Improved range of motion through external rotation and learning how to execute the internal rotation of the lift is where you see MASSIVE GAINS in muscle growth & strength.

As you can see… we don’t need to do boring band exercises like a PT patient to “heal & fix” the imbalances in our body.

There are ways we can do the same exercises you are accustomed to doing inside the gym with a ever so slight twist that will make ALL THE DIFFERENCE.

You see…I am not the type of guy to give you boring exercises that leave you with zero added muscle or strength.

sections.title: The Trapezius
sections.content:
But there is just ONE PIECE left of the puzzle we need to nail down.
And this is perhaps the most misunderstood muscle and part of shoulder training.
And when abandoned, disrespected, and overlooked, it'll make you pay for it.
And what you don’t realize is that it's the key to all of this coming together.
The final puzzle piece to becoming TRULY indestructible…

# THE TRAPEZIUS (the traps) 

This muscle is absolutely gigantic, and somehow people don’t realize that could mean there is some significance.

In a second I am going to tell you exactly how to train traps the right way.

And I know what you are thinking…Shrugs? No man…that's the issue at hand! Our Traps have 3 Parts.

And with most people equating “Trap Training” to jetting over to the dumbbell rack..picking up the heaviest pair of dumbbells and shrugging their life away

We are going to be much more precise like a SNIPER, because when we get this right, you will have LAYERS of muscles that provide that extra layer to your physique.

And those LAYERS will make you MULTIPLE times stronger…being able to stabilize heavier weight resistance with a defense system that diminishes the possibility for injury

There are 3 parts to your traps:

 - @[Upper Traps](anatomy:upper_traps)  
 - @[Middle Traps](anatomy:middle_traps)  
 - @[Lower Traps](anatomy:lower_traps) 

This isn’t just about avoiding injuries, your physique will go up a level with crazy back lines exuding out the skin.

Because you are targeting the muscles that don’t get the time of day and what's even crazier.

They require such a little period of time for ridiculous return on your body and strength.

Versus me going science on you with Blah blah blah... lets just give you the information that will get your right

The MIDDLE & LOWER part of the Trap is the money maker for you.

The problem I see over and over again, most people think “well I do deadlifts and that is good enough”

Maybe for steroid abusers but for you as a natural, that’s not going to cut it.

Because it barely scratches the surface and you are leaving a ridiculous amount of gains (muscle & strength) on the table.

So not only are you capping yourself on how strong you can get, or how much muscle you can put on your body, but the feeling of being STRONG leading to vitality and energy.

UPPER TRAPS: You should think of this as neck support which is important …but the neck is not something to completely abuse.

It's about how we add support to the neck which helps fix our head positioning but that is just the tip of the iceberg.

[EXERCISE EXAMPLE FOR THE UPPER TRAPS: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/P6ZJcShe0dI?feature=share)

[Farmer Carries + Shrugs](https://youtube.com/shorts/P6ZJcShe0dI?feature=share)

MIDDLE TRAPS: This area of the muscle sits just below the upper trapezius… going all across your shoulders. The middle trap helps you pull your shoulders back and extend your arms behind you.

[EXERCISE EXAMPLE FOR THE MIDDLE TRAPS: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/6vrlwEdrkTA?si=ujeeGkVESneRpR9h)

[Standing Reverse Incline Flyes](https://youtube.com/shorts/6vrlwEdrkTA?si=ujeeGkVESneRpR9h)

LOWER TRAPS: The lower traps play an important role in upper body strength, the health of the shoulder girdle, and overall posture, so naturally, they deserve MOST of our attention.The lower traps pull your shoulder down & helps out with shoulder blade rotation during any overhead movements.

This is why they are ESSENTIAL for stabilizing the shoulder joint and offering additional protection. This is a HUGE part of your defense system against shoulder injuries. And personally I call the Lower Trap, THE POSTURE MUSCLE.

Involved HEAVILY with maintaining proper posture during lifts and in your everyday life

[EXERCISE EXAMPLE FOR THE LOWER TRAPS: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/WCkFWnsxSpI?feature=share)

[Y Raises](https://youtube.com/shorts/WCkFWnsxSpI?feature=share)

The traps are more than just the muscle that helps you shrug your shoulders. They’re THE KEY to shoulder health, supreme posture, and IS the next level to your physique.

We train them properly…it’ll provide you that jacked upper-back look but also help prevent injuries and improve your strength in just about every upper-body lift.

There is an exercise that I rank at NUMBER 1 overall that both targets BOTH your rotator cuff muscles and traps:

IT IS THE FAMOUS “FACE PULL” BUT IT'S HOW WE DO THE FACE PULL THAT MAKES THE BIGGEST DIFFERENCE!

I see too many of you using that weird overhand grip with your palms facing the ground…they NEED to be facing each other.

[Do ‘em like this: (CLICK EACH EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/SIdGGmExFfQ?feature=share)

[FACE PULLS (BACK)](https://youtube.com/shorts/SIdGGmExFfQ?feature=share)

As you can tell from hearing all this, it is incredibly important for our shoulders to sit back.

Our body must be in alignment, otherwise the work you are doing is digging yourself into a hole. This is the real problem, you are actively putting a CAP on both your muscle growth and strength WHILE adding to chances of injury and continuing adding to your stiff ass body. The muscles and joints of your body open up to set the stage for you to unlock the level you've been working tirelessly to get to.

In ORDER of importance:

Lower Traps (MOST IMPORTANT) 1.

Mid Traps (next level) 2.

Upper Traps (last place) 3.

Last place doesn’t mean we ignore but if you want your hard work to give you results… this is how you prioritize.

sections.title: STRENGTH
sections.content:
## STRENGTH (BOULDER):

Having strong shoulders that can lift obscene weight is mainly about exercise selection. But as you get stronger, (the more output your body is capable of) the more can go wrong.

Just like a Supercar (and we can use a Mclaren as an example) is known to break down more often than Toyota.

Why?

Because the output the Mclaren is capable of is multiples more than a Toyota Camry… which means more can go wrong.

But the good news is we have FULL CONTROL over the tiny nuts and bolts involved in this entire system.

Personal story, I was military pressing 185 lbs for reps and I was proud of this because it felt like I was finally turning the corner. After doing this for a few weeks I went to conduct my business as usual… feeling great. I went to press and my trap pulled on me and I was out of the gym for a few weeks as a result. When we injure ourselves, we tend to get frustrated which is normal. But instead of thinking of it as a setback… think of it as your body’s feedback to report to you that there are things to fix.

I swear to you, every time I thought of it in this way…I’d go on to fix the problem (injury) & my muscles and strength would BLOW past my previous markers. Felt like magic and when I realized the significance of these “annoying little muscles” I began to actually look forward to it.

Because it requires such little effort to get these muscles up to speed. Strengthen your rear delts, middle traps, & your lower traps… And watch how strong you get.

Building strong shoulders is influenced heavily by exercise selection  You should be hitting PR’s often and this will ensure you do so if you follow this exactly.You are probably thinking overhead presses. How complicated can it be?

[THERE ARE 4 EXERCISES I USE TO MEASURE MY STRENGTH STANDARDS: (CLICK EACH EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/H9il_PZegSE?feature=share)

[Standing Overhead Barbell Press Standing Overhead SINGLE ARM dumbbell Press Seated Dumbbell Press Seated Barbell Press](https://youtube.com/shorts/jV3UFht-WfI?si=BJXR5nwjikHOTog5)

USE THESE 4 AT YOUR DISPOSAL.

HOWEVER if you hit a  plateau  that you can’t break through…The exercise that I found helped MOST believe it or not,  the standing overhead single arm dumbbell press.

You will very quickly find the ROOT of where your issues are stemming from on the press.

Now, what I do is work up to a 3-4 Rep Max (setting a Personal Record). Take a 3-4 minute break till you are recovered fully. Then dropping the weight by 20% and get as many reps as humanly possible. Set a Rep Personal record at that 20% drop.

Guess what you do after that? The same exact thing…drop the weight another 20% and set another REP PERSONAL RECORD.

This is going to build your endurance to sustain heavy lifting. You  should be doing one of these 4 movements listed as the VERY FIRST WORKING SETS INSIDE THE GYM.

And lifting for pure strength, of course we must have our form dialed in but none of that “slow all the way through” bologna.

Dial in on your form for the negative/eccentric portion of the rep and then explode on the rep/concentric portion of the lift.

“Focus on your form on the negative/eccentric portion of the rep” DOES NOT mean you need to go “turtle speed” , just dial in your form to where you are setting up for the press itself.

Now at this point we are now set up perfectly for the next phase of our lift.

This is where we move into growing the size of our chest, turning them from a pathetic excuse of a pectoralis major to FINALLY growing the size of your chest

Are you ready?

Probably yes considering this is what probably brought you here but understand…the more strength you are able to execute the better it facilitates the muscle growth portion.

That concludes the first portion of our lift which is HYPER FOCUSED on strength.

Now at this point we are now set up perfectly for the next phase of our lift.

This is where we move into growing the size of our shoulders.

Going from 2-dimensional to 3-Dimensional Bowling Balls.

sections.title: MUSCLE GROWTH
sections.content:
## MUSCLE GROWTH (3D SHOULDERS):

INTRODUCING THE 3D DELT FRAMEWORK. The shoulders respond to this thing known as “metabolic stress”. Basically the point in the set “when it really burns”.

DOUBLE DOWN!  Your shoulder responds best to this type of intensity. Intensity in all lifts is your best friend BUT ESPECIALLY with shoulders.

They are stubborn to grow and IF you implement the right inputs, no matter how awful your shoulder genetics are they will grow, that's a promise.

The shoulders are incredibly malleable. Now most people think “well… I already hit my front delts on the overhead lift, that's good enough“

Wrong…you were training them for strength versus hypertrophy.

Entirely different ball game

REMEMBER, we are snipers!

Precise, accurate, and nail the target between the eyes.

Unlike machine gun sprayers where they pull the trigger hope to get lucky, this leaves you very LITTLE chance to fail.

But how do we implement it in a way that does just that?

SUPERSETS: 1st Exercise: Compound Lift SUPERSET WITH 2nd Exercise: Isolation Exercise

But on the SAME EXACT MUSCLE HEAD!

EXAMPLE FOR THE ANTERIOR DELTOID (FRONT) SHOULDER HEAD:  Arnold Press (Compound Lift) followed by Front Dumbbell Raises (isolation exercise)

EXAMPLE FOR THE LATERAL DELTOID (SIDE) SHOULDER HEAD: Behind the Neck Press (Compound Lift) followed by Lateral Raises (Isolation exercise)

EXAMPLE FOR THE POSTERIOR DELTOID (BACK) SHOULDER HEAD:   Behind the Arse Upright Rows (Compound Lift) followed by FacePulls (Isolation exercise)

2-3 sets on each all till failure!

The kicker is you want to be failing between  6-9 reps   on the compound lift.  Then on the  Isolation  exercises, you want to be failing between  7-12 reps  followed by  partials.

This is simply placing our exercises in a way that gives us as much sustained effective mechanical tension on the muscle for as long as humanly possible till our body gives.

UNDERSTAND THIS NEW WAY OF HITTING YOUR SHOULDERS WILL LEAVE YOU GASSED, ANGRY, AND EXHAUSTED, BUT YOUR SHOULDERS WILL RESPOND WITH SERIOUS GROWTH.

Because you are overwhelming the muscle to a point it has legitimately no choice but to grow. And obviously you can plug and play different exercises as long as it generally fits the framework..just make sure your supersets are doubling up on the same deltoid head.

MUSCLE GROWTH:

2.POSTERIOR DELTOID (BACK SHOULDER) SUPERSET:

2-3 Sets X AMRAP (As many reps as possible till failure)

sections.title: INJURY RESILIENCE
sections.content:
## INJURY RESILIENCE:

I know many people who are plagued with injuries.

Some from the army, from sports, weightlifting in the gym, or from their work. And if you happen to know or be one of these guys, it completely tanks your way of life. Limited at every turn, have to be cautious all the time, and second guess everything you do.

WHEN LIFE IS LIVED LIKE THIS, YOU ARE ACTIVELY SUPPRESSING YOURSELF AND LIVING A LIFE IN HANDCUFFS.

And what's terrible there was not a damn thing you can do about it, until now.

Think about what life was like before your injury-ridden shoulders.

I want you to get back to that guy throwing caution to the wind with ZERO FEAR of what could go wrong.

You are playing life on your heels, you are playing life not to lose, you are playing defense.

No one likes to play life on the defensive as a default setting

Constantly factoring in: “What could go wrong?…What could go bad?”

What if you could completely trust yourself to do whatever your mind TRULY desired with the conviction to know no matter what I do… I could not injure my shoulders even if I tried with all my might.

THAT’S WHO THIS IS GUIDE FOR.

Having Big Strong 3 Dimensional Shoulders is more than just looking like a Greek Statue (although very cool and has a truckload of perks). It’s about knowing that the body part that connects your thoracic cavity to your posterior chain of the upper body is so sound and tight.

That no matter what, you are operating at your PEAK. Imagine the energy tap that presents itself to you on the other end.

THE FEELING OF KNOWING WHAT LIFE WAS LIKE WITH FRAGILE SHOULDERS AND NOW YOU CAN TRULY DO EVERYTHING YOU HAVE BEEN DREAMING TO DO LIKE BACK IN THE DAY, EXCEPT NOW YOUR SHOULDERS ARE ACTUALLY INDESTRUCTIBLE , GIGANTIC, STRONG, AND LOOK SPECTACULAR!

But what most fail to realize… The muscles you are neglecting or possibly don’t even know exist, act like an army. The more skilled soldiers you have on your team the better chance you win the war.

This is the guide that will CHANGE the game for you

There aren’t many people who have dove into shoulders the way I have because of the injuries I’ve encountered with no real answers

When you suffer from an injury, this is your body’s feedback response.

Telling you what WEAKNESSES you have in your armor.

It's your job to fix those but you don't have to do it alone anymore, because Uncle Rommy HAS YOUR BACK.

Building Injury Resilience has very little to do with the shoulder itself and more so the support system that back it up.

There are a couple muscles that matter here for you.

We talked about the  trapezius  and the  rear deltoids.

BUT there is another muscle….

THE RHOMBOIDS: The  rhomboids  consist of two muscles with the  major  and  minor sitting between your shoulder blades. This is where the magic is in both strength & added depth of muscle to your back. Functionally, they help retract the shoulder & stabilizes the upper back.

This is CRUCIAL for your posture. With STRONG rhomboids..your keep your shoulders aligned (preventing imbalances) & prevent SLOUCHING & nerd neck.

This is because retracts and stabilizes the scapula ALONG WITH assisting in shoulder rotation to then maintain proper shoulder alignment.

This muscle is PIVOTAL for both aesthetic appeal & overall proper function with real strength.

“But what is the difference between the major and minor?” Good question… But here are the 3 notable differences:

Size-  Major is bigger, minor is smaller. 1.

Where it’s located-  Minor is higher up, major is right below it. 2.

Function Difference-  Well they both do the same thing, BUT the major handles more of the heavy lifting, while the minor assists with stability and smaller movements.

3.

[ISOLATION EXERCISE FOR THE RHOMBOIDS: (CLICK EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/flhz5dtmqo4?feature=share)

[Turtle Raises](https://youtube.com/shorts/flhz5dtmqo4?feature=share)

sections.title: MOBILITY
sections.content:
## MOBILITY

Mobility is factored into our exercise selection. HOWEVER...

If you want to take it up a level, this will require some extra time (minimal) but if you are lifting the way you are supposed to this should not be an issue.

When you increase your range of motion on your exercises you:

Recruit more muscle fibers leading to greater muscle growth Burn more energy making it much more metabolically expensive Increase in strength through a LONGER range of motion/

It's a no brainer, you can move like butter and have the power of an animal

[But if you want to take your mobility up a notch, this is list of exercises that will move the needle: (CLICK EACH EXERCISE FOR A VIDEO TUTORIAL)](https://youtube.com/shorts/QSy3l2Omekw?feature=share)

[Dead Hangs Active Hangs PVC Pipe Wall Drags Full Body Mobility Movement Overhead Barbell Press Holds Overhead Squat Snatch Holds](https://youtube.com/shorts/eHn5pyH7YjQ?si=l3O1eCUPhOFOfohk)

Do these exercises and you will instantly feel relief! Very simple and to the point.

HEALING PREVIOUS TEARS AND ELIMINATING PAIN

A section that some of you have been waiting for.

“How tf do I work around my jacked shoulders???”

First and foremost …the sequencing of your lifts are probably done incorrectly on your shoulder day.

You should be training the back of your shoulders as the very first thing you do then move towards the front of your shoulders.

Again…think of it like soldiers in a war.

The more soldiers you have going into a war the better off you will be.

Problem is you have no defense system.

Your defense system, your soldiers are the muscles on the back of your shoulders through your upper back.

If you don't have those in line, then the building will fall.

First thing you want to do is start with a  REAR DELT  movement.

Why? Because this muscle is much more than the “accessory” or “second-thought” muscle that everyone thinks.

This is the first line of defense against shoulder injuries.

You should be actively trying to get stronger on these lifts.

These aren’t just “I will touch ’em up a little at the end”.

Even if you don’t have injuries, this is an INTEGRAL part of the shoulder that needs to be  PRIORITIZED.

Get stronger on these lifts, get your numbers up and take it to failure.

From there you can now enter the second part of the shoulder - the side portion of your shoulder (Lateral Head).

This is the MOST aesthetic portion of the shoulder.

Giving you that “shoulder look” you are looking for.

This is where failure training is going to make a big difference in your results.

Lean into intensity.

After you’ve gone through this correctly you will be pretty exhausted by this point and that's a good thing.

Last but not least….NOW, you can start hitting your front deltoids with another pressing movement

Will you have to drop the weight a bit due to fatigue? Yes… but the goal is to get your body back to operating at 100% health.

We are reversing and cleaning up a lot of the issues that are occurring up in your shoulders, both the muscle itself and the joint itself.

Then finish off with traps and again, NOT shrugs!

Middle to Lower Traps: The stronger you get these muscles the less chance of furthering your shoulder pain.

You will be sore but understand, and contrary to popular belief…

“Healing” is not a feel good process.

Healing hurts but understanding this pain is saving you, and it’s important. No more living your life under the same set of circumstances, forcing you into a life of suppression, and having a life of imposed limitations

sections.title: THE FLAWLESS SHOULDER DAY
sections.content:
Again to reiterate, getting over previous tears that you are still going through- The way you want to lift with a shoulder injury should follow this sequence:

REAR DELT EXERCISES 1.

SIDE DELT EXERCISES 2.

PRESS AND FRONT DELT EXERCISES 3.

TRAP EXERCISES 4.

Your most intense sets should be coming from the rear delt, side delt, and trap exercises.

Now this doesn’t mean you can’t go hard on anything front deltoid, but you sure as hell better not be going any more intense on that portion of the lift than the MUCH MORE pivotal parts.

And because I love ya for signing up….

Here is a shoulder rehab exercise sequence I used to heal my shoulder from what I thought was torn to 100% healthy in 4 DAYS (also has worked on my clients who came into my Full Scale Program with a prior injury to their shoulder.)
